sen.j: 鯉こく（こいこく）とは、輪切りにしたコイを、味噌汁で煮た料理。
sen.e: Koikoku is the name of a dish of round sliced carp stewed in miso soup.
Koikoku is the name of a dish of round sliced carp stewed in miso soup.
Koikoku is the name of a dish of round sliced carp stewed in miso soup.

sen.j: 鯉こくのこくとは、濃醤（こくしょう）という味噌を用いた汁物のことであり、鯉こくはこの濃醤の一種だった。
sen.e: Koku of koikoku comes from kokushou, a kind of soup with miso, and koikoku used to be one variation of kokushou.
Koku of koikoku comes from kokusho, a kind of soup with miso, and koikoku used to be one variation of kokusho.
Koku of koikoku comes from kokusho, a kind of soup with miso, and koikoku used to be one variation of kokusho.

sen.j: 濃醤は江戸時代までは盛んに作られていた。
sen.e: Kokushou used to be cooked popularly until the Edo era.
Kokusho used to be cooked popularly until the Edo period.
Kokusho used to be cooked popularly until the Edo period.

sen.j: 鯉ばかりでなくウナギ、フナ、スッポン、サンショウウオ、各種野鳥などでも作られていたとされる。
sen.e: It is said not only carps but eels, crucian carps, soft-shelled turtles, salamanders, and various wild fowls used to be used to make kokushou.
It is said not only carps but eels, crucian carps, soft-shelled turtles, salamanders, and various wild fowls used to be used to make kokusho.
It is said not only carps but eels, crucian carps, soft-shelled turtles, salamanders, and various wild fowls used to be used to make kokusho.

sen.j: 臭みの強い魚肉類を濃く仕立てた薄味噌で煮込んだ料理だった。
sen.e: It was a dish of fish or meat with strong smell stewed in thick miso soup.
sen.cmt: ・一原文一訳文例外対処・「濃く仕立てた薄味噌で煮込んだ」は矛盾しており表記ミスとみなし、「濃く仕立てた味噌で煮込んだ」として訳しました。
sen.e: It was a dish of fish or meat with strong smell stewed in thick miso soup.
It was a dish of fish or meat with strong smell stewed in thick miso soup.

sen.j: 江戸時代以降は濃醤はほぼ廃れてしまい、鯉を材料とした鯉こくのみが生き永らえて現在に至っている。
sen.e: Kokushou almost disappeared after Edo era, and only koikoku, a variety of kokushou with carp, remains up until today.
Kokusho almost disappeared after the Edo period, and only koikoku, a variety of kokusho with carp, remains up until today.
Kokusho almost disappeared after the Edo period, and only koikoku, a variety of kokusho with carp, remains up until today.

sen.j: 主に東日本の本州内陸部で食される。
sen.e: Koikoku is mainly eaten in eastern Japan in the inland area of Honshu.
Koikoku is mainly eaten in eastern Japan in the inland area of Honshu.
Koikoku is mainly eaten in eastern Japan in the inland area of Honshu.

sen.j: 池波正太郎の「鬼平犯科帳｣シリーズにも登場するように、江戸の人間の好物でもあったらしい。
sen.e: As described in Shotaro IKENAMI's "Onihei Hankacho", it seems to be a favorite dish of Edo people.
sen.cmt: ※登録済みの定訳は「Onihe」となっていましたが、「Onihei」に直して使用しました。
sen.e: As described in Shotaro IKENAMI's "Onihei Hankacho," it seems to have been a favorite dish of Edo people.
sen.cmt: カンマの位置を移動、seems to be→seems to have beenに修正
sen.e: As described in Shotaro IKENAMI's "Onihei Hankacho," it seems to have been a favorite dish of Edo people.

sen.j: 鯉こくは、出産後の母乳の出を良くすると言われている。
sen.e: It is said koikoku helps a mother after giving birth to milk well.
It is said koikoku helps a mother after giving birth to milk well.
It is said koikoku helps a mother after giving birth to milk well.

sen.j: 1746年（延享3年）1月6日には信州佐久郡岩村田の割元職の篠澤佐五右衛門包道が伊勢神宮神官福島鳥羽太夫に鯉こくを献上している。
sen.e: On January 6, 1746, 篠澤佐五右衛門包道, an official liaison (warimoto) of Iwamurata, Saku County, Shinshu, presented koikoku to Toba FUKUSHIMA, a low-ranking Shinto priest of Ise Jingu Shrine.
On January 6, 1746, 篠澤佐五右衛門包道, an official liaison (warimoto) of Iwamurata, Saku County, Shinshu, presented koikoku to Toba FUKUSHIMA, a low-ranking Shinto priest of Ise Jingu Shrine.
On January 6, 1746, 篠澤佐五右衛門包道, an official liaison (warimoto) of Iwamurata, Saku County, Shinshu, presented koikoku to Toba FUKUSHIMA, a low-ranking Shinto priest of Ise Jingu Shrine.

sen.j: この文献は八代末裔の篠澤明剛氏が所有している。
sen.e: The document is kept by Akiyoshi SASAZAWA, the eighth descendant.
The document is kept by Akiyoshi SASAZAWA, the eighth descendant.
The document is kept by Akiyoshi SASAZAWA, the eighth descendant.

sen.j: 篠澤家は江戸時代より宿を営んでおり、毎年1月6日にはこの宿にて当時の鯉こくを再現調理するイベント（佐久鯉誕生の日）が行われている。
sen.e: The Sasazawa family has run an inn from the Edo era, and they have an event every January 6th at this inn to reproduce koikoku in the original style (the birthday of Sakukoi (Saku carp)).
The Sasazawa family has run an inn from the Edo period, and they have an event every January 6th at this inn to reproduce koikoku in the original style (the birthday of Sakukoi (Saku carp)).
The Sasazawa family has run an inn from the Edo period, and they have an event every January 6th at this inn to reproduce koikoku in the original style (the birthday of Sakukoi (Saku carp)).

sen.j: ちなみに広島県(尾三地区)では、鯉こくは好意を持っている相手に対して鯉の手料理を作って、好きな気持ちを伝えるという儀式があり、現在でも伝承されている。
sen.e: In Hiroshima Prefecture there is a rite to cook carp for a person one loves to communicate the affection, which is handed down till today.
In Hiroshima Prefecture there is a rite to cook carp for a person one loves to communicate the affection, which has been handed down till today.
sen.cmt: is handed down→has been handed downとしました。
sen.e: In Hiroshima Prefecture there is a rite to cook carp for a person one loves to communicate the affection, which has been handed down till today.

sen.j: 鯉は鱗を取り、筒切りにする。
sen.e: Remove the scales from a carp and cut in round slices.
Remove the scales from a carp and cut in round slices.
Remove the scales from a carp and cut in round slices.

sen.j: 臭み取りのために、鯉をざるにおき、湯をかけ回す。
sen.e: Place the carp on the colander and pour hot water to remove the smell.
Place the carp on the colander and pour hot water to remove the smell.
Place the carp on the colander and pour hot water to remove the smell.

sen.j: 鍋に水、日本酒、味噌、砂糖を入れ煮立ったら鯉を入れる。
sen.e: Heat water, sake, miso, and sugar in a pot, and after it boils add carp.
Heat water, sake, miso, and sugar in a pot, and after it boils add carp.
Heat water, sake, miso, and sugar in a pot, and after it boils add carp.

sen.j: もう一度煮立ったら弱火にし、灰汁を取り1時間程度煮込む。
sen.e: Lower the flame after it boils again, skim off the scum, and stew for about an hour.
Lower the flame after it boils again, skim off the scum, and stew for about an hour.
Lower the flame after it boils again, skim off the scum, and stew for about an hour.

sen.j: 椀に汁と切り身を盛りつけ、細ネギ、ユズをのせる。
sen.e: Serve carp and soup in a bowl and add strips of green onion and citron.
Serve carp and soup in a bowl and add strips of green onion and citron.
Serve carp and soup in a bowl and add strips of green onion and citron.

sen.j: 好みで粉山椒、七味唐辛子をふりかけてもおいしい。
sen.e: You may sprinkle sansho powder or shichimi togarashi (a mixture of red cayenne pepper and other aromatic spices) if you like.
You may sprinkle sansho powder or shichimi togarashi (a mixture of red cayenne pepper and other aromatic spices) if you like.
You may sprinkle sansho powder or shichimi togarashi (a mixture of red cayenne pepper and other aromatic spices) if you like.

sen.j: 〈ポイント〉
sen.e: <Points>
<Tips>
<Tips>

sen.j: 味噌は一般的に赤味噌を使用、一部では白味噌も。
sen.e: In general red bean paste is used and sometimes white bean paste.
In general red bean paste is used and sometimes white bean paste.
In general red bean paste is used and sometimes white bean paste.

sen.j: 地域によっては鱗を取らず煮込む事も。
sen.e: In some regions carp is cooked without being scaled.
In some regions carp is cooked without being scaled.
In some regions carp is cooked without being scaled.

sen.j: 鯉の頭を一緒に煮込むと、出汁が効いてより美味に。
sen.e: It becomes richly flavored and tastes better if cooked with the head of carp.
It becomes richly flavored and tastes better if cooked with the head of carp.
It becomes richly flavored and tastes better if cooked with the head of carp.

sen.j: 鯉のほか豆腐やダイコン等の具を入れることもある。
sen.e: In addition to carp sometimes other ingredients are added such as tofu (bean curd) and daikon (Japanese radish).
In addition to carp sometimes other ingredients are added such as tofu (bean curd) and daikon (Japanese radish).
In addition to carp sometimes other ingredients are added such as tofu (bean curd) and daikon (Japanese radish).
